API Reference

shapes modules

class shapes.invertible_nn.ConvexDiffeo(input_size=2, n_unit=50, symmetries=None)[source]

Bases: Module

Neural parametrization of a convex diffeomorphism.

This class represents a smooth diffeomorphism

φ : B(0, 1) ⊂ ℝᵈ → Ω ⊂ ℝᵈ

mapping the unit ball onto a convex domain Ω. The map is defined via a learned convex gauge function G:

φ(x) = x · ||x|| / G(x)

Optionally, symmetry constraints can be enforced by averaging the gauge over a finite symmetry group.

Parameters:

  • mesh_length (optional) – Reserved for future discretization / meshing purposes.

  • input_size (int) – Ambient dimension d.

  • n_unit (int) – Number of hidden units in the convex gauge network.

  • symmetries (iterable of callables, optional) – Group actions g(x) enforcing symmetry through averaging.

center_of_gravity(n_points=50000)[source]

Compute the center of gravity of Ω.

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (1, d)

dirichlet_eigenvalues(n_ev=10, n_sources=200, n_quad_points=100000, n_quad_points_bd=200, eps=1.0, rbf='thin_plate', normalize=False, bd_penalization=100000.0)[source]

evaluate_rbf_function(x_eval, sources, coeffs, eps=1.0, rbf='thin_plate')[source]

Evaluate an RBF expansion:

u(x) = Σ_j c_j φ(x - y_j)

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (N_eval,)

forward(x, eps=1e-12)[source]

Evaluate the diffeomorphism φ(x).

Parameters:

  • x (torch.Tensor, shape (B, d)) – Points in the unit ball.

  • eps (float) – Small stabilization constant to avoid division by zero.

Returns:

Points in the target convex domain Ω.

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (B, d)

gelsd_like_lstsq(A, b, rcond=1e-15)[source]

Solve a least-squares problem using SVD (GELSD-like).

This function mimics the behavior of LAPACK’s GELSD while remaining compatible with CUDA.

Solves:

min ||Ax - b||₂

and returns the minimum-norm solution.

Parameters:

  • A (torch.Tensor, shape (M, N))

  • b (torch.Tensor, shape (M,) or (M, K))

  • rcond (float) – Relative cutoff for small singular values.

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (N,) or (N, K)

generalized_sym_eig(A, M, k=None, eps_jitter=1e-12, return_eigvecs=True)[source]

Solve the generalized symmetric eigenproblem:

A c = λ M c

using Cholesky reduction.

Eigenvectors are normalized in the M-inner product.

Returns:

  • eigvals (torch.Tensor)

  • eigvecs (torch.Tensor)

grad_psi(x, y)[source]

Gradient of the fundamental solution with respect to x.

Computes:

  • y (torch.Tensor, shape (N_y, d))

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (N_x, N_y, d)

jacobian_cofactor_matrix(x)[source]

Compute the cofactor (adjugate) matrix of the Jacobian.

This matrix naturally appears in surface measure transformations under φ.

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (B, d, d)

jacobian_regularizer(n_points=500)[source]

Regularizer preventing Jacobian degeneracy.

Returns the maximum condition number of Dφ(x) over sampled points on the sphere.

Return type:

torch.Tensor (scalar)

perimeter(n_points=50000)[source]

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (1,)

psi(x, y)[source]

Fundamental solution of the Laplacian.

Constructs the matrix:

[ φ(x_i - y_j) ]_{i,j}

where φ is the fundamental solution of the Laplacian in ℝᵈ:

  • d = 2 : φ(r) = -log|r|

  • d ≥ 3 : φ(r) = |r|^{2-d}

Parameters:

  • x (torch.Tensor, shape (N_x, d)) – Evaluation points.

  • y (torch.Tensor, shape (N_y, d)) – Source points.

Returns:

Pairwise evaluations of φ(x_i - y_j).

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (N_x, N_y)

rbf(x, y, eps=1.0, rbf='thin_plate')[source]

Evaluate radial basis functions φ(|x - y|).

Supports several kernels: - Gaussian - Multiquadric - Inverse multiquadric - Thin-plate spline - Wendland C²

Returns:

RBF matrix.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

sample_ball(n_points=50000, requires_grad=False, random=False)[source]

Sample points uniformly inside the unit ball B(0,1).

Sampling is performed by rejection from the hypercube [-1,1]^d.

Parameters:

  • n_points (int) – Approximate number of accepted samples.

  • requires_grad (bool) – Whether returned points require gradients.

  • random (bool) – If True, sample randomly; otherwise use a Cartesian grid.

Returns:

Points inside the unit ball.

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (N, d)

sample_sphere(n_points=50000, seed=1073, requires_grad=False)[source]

Sample points uniformly on the unit sphere S^{d-1}.

Sampling strategy depends on the dimension: - 2D: exact angular parametrization - 3D: Fibonacci lattice - d>3: projection from the unit ball

Parameters:

  • n_points (int) – Number of sampled points.

  • requires_grad (bool) – Whether returned points require gradients.

Returns:

Points on the unit sphere.

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (N, d)

torsional_rigidity(n_points=20000, tol=0.002, n_sources_grid=None, offset_grid=None)[source]

Compute torsional rigidity using adaptive parameter search.

A grid search is performed over: - number of sources - offset distance outside the domain

until the relative boundary error is below tol.

Parameters:

  • n_points (int) – Number of quadrature points.

  • tol (float) – Target relative boundary error.

  • n_sources_grid (list[int], optional) – Candidate numbers of sources.

  • offset_grid (list[float], optional) – Candidate source offsets.

Returns:

Estimated torsional rigidity.

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (1,)

torsional_rigidity_(n_points=20000, n_sources=300, offset=0.1)[source]

Compute torsional rigidity for fixed parameters.

Solves the Poisson problem:
-Δu = 1 in Ω

u = 0 on ∂Ω

using a boundary collocation method with Green functions.

Returns:

  • torsion (torch.Tensor, shape (1,))

  • rel_err (torch.Tensor) – Relative boundary error.

volume(n_points=50000)[source]

Monte Carlo estimate of the volume |Ω|.

Uses the change-of-variables formula:

|Ω| = ∫_B |det Dφ(x)| dx

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (1,)

willmore_energy(n_points=50000)[source]

Compute the Willmore energy:

∫_{∂Ω} H² dS

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (1,)

class shapes.gauge_functions.LSEGauge(input_size=2, n_unit=50, beta=10)[source]

Bases: Module

Log-Sum-Exp (LSE) smoothed gauge function.

This module represents a smooth approximation of the gauge (Minkowski functional) of a convex polygon or polytope.

Given a convex set Ω ⊂ ℝᵈ containing the origin, its gauge is:

γ_Ω(x) = inf { t > 0 : x ∈ tΩ }

This implementation approximates the gauge using a log-sum-exp (soft maximum) of linear functionals, yielding a smooth, positively 1-homogeneous, convex function.

The functional form is:

γ(x) ≈ ||x|| · (1/β) · log ∑ₖ exp(⟨wₖ, x / ||x||⟩)

where:

  • {wₖ} are learned directions

  • β > 0 controls the sharpness of the approximation

Parameters:

  • input_size (int, optional) – Ambient dimension d.

  • n_unit (int, optional) – Number of linear directions (facets).

  • beta (float, optional) – Initial inverse temperature for the log-sum-exp smoothing. Larger values give sharper (less smooth) approximations.

forward(x)[source]

Evaluate the smoothed gauge function.

The input is decomposed into direction and magnitude to enforce positive 1-homogeneity:

γ(λx) = λ γ(x), λ ≥ 0

Parameters:

x (torch.Tensor, shape (B, d)) – Input vectors.

Returns:

Gauge values γ(x).

Return type:

torch.Tensor, shape (B, 1)

shapes.plot_utils.plot_all_shapes(models, x, out_folder, plot_meshes=False, video=False)[source]

Plot a diagram and a collection of shapes generated by ConvexDiffeo models.

This function: - Saves each model to disk - Plots the corresponding shape - Generates a CSV file mapping diagram points to shape images

The CSV file has columns:

img_src, x, y

Parameters:

  • models (list[ConvexDiffeo]) – List of trained models defining shapes.

  • x (array-like, shape (N, 2)) – Diagram coordinates associated with each model.

  • out_folder (str) – Output directory where plots, models, and CSV are saved.

  • plot_meshes (bool, optional) – If True, also plot a finite-element mesh of the 2D shape.

  • video (bool, optional) – If True, generate rotating 3D videos instead of static images.

shapes.plot_utils.plot_diagram(x, output, xlim=(0, 1), ylim=(0, 1), color=None, cmap='cool_r')[source]

Plot a 2D diagram of points.

Intended for visualizing parameter spaces or embeddings associated with shape collections.

Parameters:

  • x (array-like, shape (N, 2)) – Point coordinates.

  • output (str) – Path where the image is saved.

  • xlim (tuple, optional) – X-axis limits.

  • ylim (tuple, optional) – Y-axis limits.

  • color (array-like or None) – Scalar values used for coloring points.

  • cmap (str) – Matplotlib colormap name.

shapes.plot_utils.plot_shape(model, output, n_points=500, video=False, plot_mesh=False)[source]

Dispatch shape plotting based on dimension and output type.

Parameters:

  • model (ConvexDiffeo) – Shape-defining model.

  • output (str) – Output file path.

  • n_points (int) – Resolution of boundary sampling.

  • video (bool) – If True and dim=3, generate a rotating video.

  • plot_mesh (bool) – If True and dim=2, overlay a finite-element mesh.

Plot the boundary of a 2D convex shape.

Parameters:

  • model (ConvexDiffeo) – 2D shape model.

  • output (str) – Output image path.

  • n_points (int) – Number of boundary samples.

Render a 3D shape using PyVista (static image).

Parameters:

  • model (ConvexDiffeo) – 3D shape model.

  • output (str) – Output image path.

  • n_points (int) – Sphere resolution.

  • window_size (tuple) – Rendering window size in pixels.

  • output (str) – Output video path (mp4).

  • n_points (int) – Sphere resolution.

  • window_size (tuple) – Rendering window size in pixels.
